patterns: Should I have a masectomy or lumphectomy
responses: A lumpectomy, or breast-conserving surgery, is a procedure where only the portion of the breast containing the cancer and a margin of surrounding tissue is removed. A mastectomy is the surgical removal of the entire breast

patterns: Will I feel sick from radiation
responses: It is normal to be concerned about radiation, but you won't be radioactive and you won't lose your hair. For some of the short term side effects please check here https://www.komen.org/breast-cancer/treatment/type/radiation-therapy/side-effects/

patterns: Will I feel sick from chemo
responses: Not all women with breast cancer will need chemo, but there are several situations in which chemo may be recommended. Before and after surgery and for metastatic breast cancer. For a list of common side effects check in here https://www.cancer.org/treatment/treatments-and-side-effects/physical-side-effects.html

patterns: Should I do a self check
How often should I perform a breast exam
responses: Adult women of all ages are encouraged to perform breast self-exams at least once a month. This can be done in the shower, in front of a mirror, or laying down to check for changes in your breasts.

Going flat is choosing not to have breast reconstruction after a masectomy. Here is a link on different types of breast reconstruction https://www.mskcc.org/news/breast-reconstruction-deciding-between-implant-and-flap-surgery

patterns: What will my sex life be like after breast cancer
responses:
Does breast cancer affect your sex life?
The breast cancer experience slows down your body. It takes longer to do lots of things, including getting interested in and starting and finishing sexual intercourse. Sex may be uncomfortable or even painful if you've been thrown into sudden-onset menopause. No surprise that you tend to have less sex, for now.
